Effect of singlet oxygen O 2
(a
1 Δ g
) molecules produced in a gas discharge plasma on the
ignition of hydrogen-oxygen mixtures

text.front:
IOP PUBLISHING
PLASMA SOURCES SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
Plasma Sources Sci. Technol. 20 (2011) 045002 (11pp)
doi:10.1088/0963-0252/20/4/045002
Effect of singlet oxygen O 2 (a 1 ∆ g )
molecules produced in a gas discharge
plasma on the ignition of
hydrogen-oxygen mixtures
N A Popov
Skobel'tsyn Institute of Nuclear Physics, Moscow State University, Leninskie gory, Moscow 119991,
Russia
E-mail: NPopov@mics.msu.su
Received 31 October 2010, in final form 24 March 2011
Published 25 May 2011
Online at stacks.iop.org/PSST/20/045002
Abstract
A kinetic model describing the impact of singlet delta oxygen O 2 (a 1
g ) produced in a gas
discharge plasma on the evolution of hydrogen-oxygen mixture composition is developed. In
the framework of this model the possibility of describing all the main experimental data on the
dynamics of O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching in H 2 : O 2 gas mixtures in the temperature range
T 0 = 300-1050 K is shown. Most of the collisions between singlet oxygen molecules and
atomic hydrogen, O 2 (a 1
g ) + H, lead to quenching of O 2 (a 1
g ). The efficiency of this
interaction channel is more than 80% and the fraction of the reaction
H + O 2 (a 1
g ) → OH + O( 3 P) is only 10-20%. The impact of singlet oxygen O 2 (a 1
g )
admixture on the ignition of H 2 : O 2 mixtures is investigated. The dominant process
determining the degree of O 2 (a 1
g ) impact is its deactivation by HO 2 molecules. As a result,
in H 2 : O 2 mixtures of high pressure, where the number density of the produced HO 2
molecules can be sufficiently high, the impact of singlet oxygen on the ignition delay time of
these mixtures turns out to be relatively weak. This effect becomes even less noticeable if
admixtures of atomic oxygen are present in the mixture. Oxygen atoms produced by the
discharge are more efficient in the ignition of hydrogen-oxygen and hydrogen-air mixtures
than O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules. Thus, to reduce the ignition delay time and to decrease the
temperature threshold of combustive mixtures, the use of gas discharge systems providing the
efficient production of atomic particles is recommended.
(Some figures in this article are in colour only in the electronic version)
text.body:
1. Introduction
To date, there have been numerous papers in which the effect
of chemically active radical admixtures on the shift of ignition
temperature threshold and decrease in the induction delay
time of combustive mixtures was studied. In these studies, to
obtain an initial concentration of chemically active particles,
UV radiation, electric discharges, electron beams, etc were
used [1]. A distinctive feature of the electric discharge effect
on combustive mixtures is that, as a result, various degrees
of freedom of molecules are excited [1-5]. Depending on
the value of the reduced electric field, E/N (N is the gas
number density), formed in the studied discharges, production
of different kinds of chemically active particles occurs. At high
E/N, a considerable part of the discharge energy is spent on
ionization and dissociation of molecules [6, 7], and in relatively
low fields, an efficient excitation of electronic states O 2 (a 1
g ),
O 2 (b 1 +
g ) takes place [8-10].
Thus, one of the priorities is a comparative analysis
of the effect of various chemically active particles on the
characteristics of the ignition process. This will allow us
to choose a set of particles that is optimal with respect
text.front:
0963-0252/11/045002+11$33.00
1
© 2011 IOP Publishing Ltd Printed in the UK & the USA
Plasma Sources Sci. Technol. 20 (2011) 045002
N A Popov
text.body:
to the effect on ignition and, perhaps, to determine the
discharge characteristics providing nonequilibrium production
of chemically active particles in optimal ratios.
The problem of combustion and detonation initiation in
fuel mixtures in the presence of oxygen molecules O 2 (b 1 +
g ),
O 2 (a 1
g ) excited in a gas discharge plasma has recently been
studied [11-17]. In [11], apparently for the first time, reactions
involving O 2 (a 1
g ) were used to explain the experimentally
observed increase in flame propagation velocity in H 2 : O 2
mixtures, after excitation of oxygen by an electric discharge.
In these experiments, the oxygen flow passed through the glow
discharge (I = 5-85 mA) and then molecular hydrogen was
added to this flow. The resulting mixture (pressure P 0 =
50 Torr, T 0 = 293 K) contained 7% H 2 +93% O 2 and the O( 3 P),
O 3 , O 2 (a 1
g ), O 2 (b 1 +
g ) particles produced in the discharge.
The obtained mixture was ignited by a pulsed spark discharge
with subsequent measurements of normal flame velocity and
the axial profile of the gas temperature.
At discharge currents exceeding 17 mA, the flame velocity
almost doubled. But for all that, the increase in the gas
temperature in the discharge did not exceed 5-10 K. The results
of simulations [12, 16] confirmed the assumption that the
impact of a glow discharge in oxygen on the flame velocity is
likely associated with the participation of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules,
produced in the discharge, in the ignition processes.
In [14-16], the results from theoretical studies of the
impact of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules on the ignition delay time of
H 2 : O 2 : O 2 (a 1
g ) mixtures are presented. A possibility of
a sufficient reduction in the ignition temperature threshold
and in the induction times of hydrogen-oxygen mixtures is
shown when the fraction of singlet delta oxygen (SDO) is
[O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 ] 1%.
One of the important processes that determines the
efficiency of SDO impact on the ignition delay time is the
following:
O 2 (a 1
g ) + H 2 → OH + OH.
(1)
This process can result in sufficiently more rapid production of
chemically active particles by adding SDO. The rate constant
of reaction (1) increases essentially with the rise in gas
temperature. The corresponding dependence k 1 (T ) obtained
in [15] is shown in figure 1 (curve 1).
Along with this, quenching of O 2 (a 1
g ) by hydrogen
molecules is also possible:
O 2 (a 1
g ) + H 2 → O 2 + H 2 .
(2)
The rate constant of reaction (2) at T = 300 K was measured
in several experiments (see [18]). The calculation results of the
dependence of this reaction rate constant on gas temperature
are given in [19]. The approach adopted in this work is based on
assumptions that the spin ban on the transition O 2 (a 1
g ) →
O 2 (X 3 −
g ) is withdrawn by taking into account spin-orbit
interaction inside the O 2 molecule, that the kinetic energy
of relative motion is much more than the potential energy
of molecular interaction, and that the transition probability is
small. The last two conditions allow us to apply perturbation
theory. The results from the calculation of the dependence
k 2 (T ) [19] are shown in figure 1 (curve 2). Here (curve 3), the

Figure 1. Dependences of reaction rate constants on
temperature: 1: O 2 (a 1
g ) + H 2 → 2 • OH [15];
2: O 2 (a 1
g ) + H 2 → O 2 + H 2 [19]; 3: experimental data [20].
results of the measurement of the quenching rate of O 2 (a 1
g )
obtained in [20] are also presented in the temperature range
T = 500-1000 K. In this paper the temporal dynamics of
O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching in a H 2 : O 2 mixture (with the fraction
of hydrogen less than 2-3%) was measured. In [20], the
main mechanism of SDO quenching was associated with
reaction (2). As seen from figure 1, the experimentally
obtained rates of O 2 (a 1
g ) losses far exceed both the rate
constant of reaction k 1 (T ) [15] and the rate constant of SDO
deactivation k 2 (T ) [19]. One of the reasons for such a
difference might be the fact that the analysis of experimental
results [20] does not take into account the specifics of the
considered mixture in which chain chemical reactions can
proceed in the temperature range T 0 = 500-1000 K. As a
result, particles that can actively quench the SDO molecules
are produced, for example, H and HO 2 . Therefore, a further
numerical analysis of experimental results [20] is necessary to
determine the possible reasons for the high rate of O 2 (a 1
g )
loss under these conditions.
Other important processes for the combustion problems
are the following:
H + O 2 (a 1
g ) → OH + O( 3 P),
(3)
H + O 2 (a 1
g ) → H + O 2 .
(4)
These reactions were investigated experimentally in [21, 22]
in the temperature ranges T = 300-431 K and T = 520-
930 K, respectively. The total rate constant of processes (3)
and (4) was measured in these papers, and, according to [22],
reaction (3) is dominant. However, it has been shown in more
recent studies [23] that k 3 /(k 3 + k 4 ) 0.1 in the temperature
range T = 300-437 K. Thus, the ratio between the reaction
rates k 3 : k 4 remains unknown.
In [23, 24], the following process:
O 2 (a 1
g ) + HO 2 → O 2 + HO *
2
(5)
was included to explain the experimental results concerning the
temporal dynamics of the atomic hydrogen concentration when

a The coefficient α ∼ = 0.2 is determined in the given work (see below).
O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules were added to a mixture of H : H 2 : O 2 .
The rate constant of this reaction is k 5 = 2.0 × 10 −12 cm 3 s −1 ,
according to [23, 24]. In [25], higher rates of SDO quenching
by HO 2 molecules were reported, which amounted to k 5 =
3.0×10 −11 cm 3 s −1 . Consequently, reaction (5) can also affect
the dynamics of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules and the ignition delay
time of H 2 : O 2 : O 2 (a 1
g ) mixtures.
The aim of this paper is to analyze the results from
the mentioned experiments and to explain the discrepancy
of data obtained. Based on this analysis, recommendations
concerning the rates of the main processes involving O 2 (a 1
g )
(1)-(5) will be provided. This will make it possible to estimate
the impact of SDO molecules on the induction time and shift
of ignition temperature threshold for H 2 : O 2 mixtures. The
efficiency of singlet oxygen as an ignition initiator is analyzed
and compared with the efficiency of O( 3 P) atoms.
2. Model description
In [1], a model of ignition of hydrogen-oxygen mixtures
is described. The evolution of mixture composition was
described by a set of ordinary differential equations for
individual reagent concentrations N j :
dN j
dt
= F +
j − F −
j ,
where F +
j and F −
j are the rates of production and consumption
of particle j , respectively [1].
The expression for enthalpy H of the mixture is
represented as
H = N −1 µ −1
S
j =1
h 0j N j + C p • T ,
P =
ρ • RT
µ
,
µ= N −1
S
j =1
µ j • N j ,
N =
S
j =1
N j .
Here, T is the gas temperature; h 0j is the enthalpy of formation
of the j th component at T = 298 K; S is the number of species;
C p is the constant pressure specific heat capacity of the mixture
(computed using specified data); P and ρ are the pressure and
density of gas, respectively; µ j is the molar weight of the j th
component of the mixture; R is the universal gas constant.
To test the developed model, we performed calculations
of the dependences of ignition delay time of H 2 : O 2 : N 2 : Ar
mixtures on the initial temperature in a broad range of pressures
and stoichiometric coefficients, as well as the dynamics of the
main components of hydrogen-oxygen mixtures during their
oxidation process. By comparing the results of calculations
with experimental data, we can conclude about the adequacy
of the description of available experimental results and the
possibility of using the developed kinetic model for predictive
calculations. In this paper, the system of reactions [1]
was supplemented by processes involving singlet oxygen
molecules O 2 (a 1
g ) and O 2 (b 1 +
g ). These processes are
given in table 1.
3. Calculation results and discussion
3.1. Reaction H + O 2 (a 1
g ) at T
430 K
In all the further considered experiments (except in cases
explicitly stated) studies were carried out in a flow reactor with
a system of flow mixing. O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules were produced,
typically, in a microwave discharge (in oxygen or O 2 : Ar,
O 2 : He mixtures). O( 3 P) atoms, which are also produced in
the discharge, were removed in reactions with mercury oxide
HgO, which coated the walls of the tube. Hydrogen atoms
were produced in a microwave discharge in argon (or helium)
with the admixture of H 2 .
In [21], the quenching of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules by atomic
hydrogen was studied in a mixture of H 2 : O 2 : Ar at P = 0.3-
0.9 Torr. The experiments were conducted both in the presence
of O( 3 P) atoms and without them. After mixing the flows of
excited hydrogen and oxygen, temporal dynamics of O, H,
and also OH and O 2 (a 1
g ) densities was studied using an
electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer. Based
on these data, the rate of O 2 (a 1
g ) deactivation by hydrogen
atoms (k 3 + k 4 ) was determined at T = 300-431 K. To reduce
the probability of heterogeneous losses of active particles, the
tube walls were covered with orthoboric acid. As a result,
the reactions at the surface had practically no effect on the
dynamics of the main studied components and this was verified
experimentally.

Plasma Sources Sci. Technol. 20 (2011) 045002
N A Popov

Figure 2. Temporal dynamics of the main components of the
mixture H 2 : O 2 : O 2 (a 1
g ) : Ar at T = 300 K and at the ratio of
reaction rates k 3 : k 4 = 2 : 8. Dots correspond to the calculated
values of 2.17 • [O( 3 P)] at O 2 (a 1
g ) = 0. The initial concentrations
of components are Ar = 9.1 × 10 15 cm −3 ; O 2 = 5.3 × 10 15 cm −3 ;
H 2 = 7.4 × 10 14 cm −3 ; H = 4.4 × 10 14 cm −3 and
O 2 (a 1
g ) = 5.5 × 10 14 cm −3 .
As an example, figure 2 shows the temporal dynamics
of the different components of the mixture which has the
following initial composition: Ar = 9.1 × 10 15 cm −3 , O 2 =
5.3×10 15 cm −3 , H 2 = 7.4×10 14 cm −3 , H = 4.4×10 14 cm −3 ,
O 2 (a 1
g ) = 5.5 × 10 14 cm −3 , T 0 = 300 K. Under these
conditions the main channel of loss of SDO molecules is
the reactions with H atoms, the decay of O 2 (a 1
g ) being
monoexponential [21]. It is therefore necessary that the
hydrogen number density H(t) varies only slightly with time.
As seen from the calculation results presented in figure 2, this
condition is fulfilled.
In [23], another mechanism of SDO quenching associated
with reaction (5) O 2 (a 1
g ) + HO 2 → O 2 + HO 2 was
proposed to explain the experimental results [21]. According
to the calculations given in figure 2, the concentration of
HO 2 molecules within the considered time interval remains
practically constant, being ≈3 × 10 10 cm −3 in total. In this
case, the frequency of O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching in reaction (5)
does not exceed ν a
0.6 s −1 , which is much lower than
the experimentally observed value under these conditions,
ν a ∼ = 8 s −1 [21]. So, the mechanism of O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching
proposed in [23] is not sufficient under the conditions of
experiment [21].
It was also shown in [21] that the concentration of
atomic oxygen increased under these conditions by adding
molecules of O 2 (a 1
g ). These data can be used to determine
the fractions of reaction channels (3) and (4). According
to [21], the addition of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules with number
density 5.5 × 10 14 cm −3 to the studied mixture increases the
concentration of atomic oxygen by a factor of 2.17. To
obtain the value of ξ = [O( 3 P)]/[O( 3 P)] 0 = 2.17 in the
calculations, it is necessary to suggest that the ratio of reaction
rates k 3 : k 4 is about 2 : 8 (see figure 3). It is worth mentioning
that taking into account the uncertainty associated with the
heterogeneous recombination of atomic oxygen on the tube

walls has practically no effect on the value of ξ (in the
frequency range ν get = 2-20 s −1 ).
The reaction H + O 2 (a 1
g ) → OH + O was also studied
in [23] under the conditions T = 295-423 K, P = 0.5-
7 Torr. Here, as in [21], the mixing of hydrogen and oxygen
flows excited by microwave discharges took place. The
concentrations of O and H atoms were measured by the
radiation absorption technique at wavelengths λ = 130.5 nm
and λ = 121.6 nm, respectively. To determine the OH number
density, the laser-induced fluorescence (LIF) technique was
used for the transition OH(X 2 , v = 0) → OH(A 2 , v =
0) (λ = 308.2 nm). The content of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules was
determined by the value and dynamics of the photoionization
current formed as a result of absorption of Ar lamp radiation
(λ = 106.7 nm) by SDO molecules.
Figure 4 shows the experimental data [23] and the
calculation results of the temporal dynamics of some
components produced in a mixture of He = 3.3 × 10 16 cm −3 ,
O 2 = 6.0×10 15 cm −3 and H = 5.0×10 11 cm −3 at T = 300 K.
The main reactions determining the evolution of number
density of H and O( 3 P) atoms and OH and HO 2 molecules
in this case are the following:
H + O 2 + M → HO 2 + M,
(6)
H + HO 2 → OH + OH,
(7)
OH + OH → O + H 2 O,
(8)
O + HO 2 → OH + O 2 ,
(9)
O + OH → H + O 2 .
(10)
It should be noted that in order to compare the calculation
results with the experimental data on the temporal dynamics of
OH radicals, the rate constant of reaction (7) was taken equal to
k 7 = 3.8×10 −11 cm 3 s −1 as proposed in [23]. This value is 1.7
times less than that recommended in [29]. Studies [23, 24, 26]
were performed using identical techniques and even with the

Figure 4. Temporal dynamics of the main components of the
mixture He = 3.3 × 10 16 cm −3 , O 2 = 6.0 × 10 15 cm −3 ,
H = 5.0 × 10 11 cm −3 , O 2 (a 1
g ) = 0 at T = 300 K. Signs
correspond to the experimental data [23].
same diagnostics (absorption of UV radiation and LIF). One
of the reasons for the difference in results could be the errors
in determining the absolute values of H atom number density.
As shown by our calculations, a decrease in the absolute values
of [H] 0 concentration by approximately 22-25% allows us to
describe the temporal dynamics of OH radicals measured in
[23] at a value of k 7 = 6.6×10 −11 cm 3 s −1 , which corresponds
to the recommendations [29].
Addition of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules to the mixture results in
a sufficient increase in the concentration of produced O( 3 P)
atoms, but it decreases OH density and the rate of hydrogen
atom losses [23, 24]. To explain such dynamics of H atoms, we
should assume the possibility of destruction of HO 2 molecules
in the reaction with O 2 (a 1
g ) and production of hydrogen
atoms in this reaction.
It is well known that HO 2 molecules are produced in a
highly excited state in process (6):
H + O 2 + M → HO *
2 + M.
In this paper, the dissociation of HO *
2 molecules was
additionally considered to explain the results [23, 24]:
O 2 (a 1
g ) + HO *
2 → H + 2 • O 2 .
(11)
In addition, the possible quenching of HO *
2 molecules was
taken into account [24]:
HO *
2 + He → HO 2 + He
k = 1.7 × 10 −12 cm 3 s −1 .
The calculated and experimental temporal dynamics of
the main considered components are given in figure 5. The
initial conditions were taken to be the same as in figure 4 but
the addition of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules ([O 2 (a 1
g )] = 2.6 ×
10 14 cm −3 ) was taken into account. The calculation results
were obtained at k 11 = 5.0 × 10 −10 cm 3 s −1 . Just as in
[21], the production of O( 3 P) atoms under these conditions

Figure 5. Temporal dynamics of the main components
of the mixture under the conditions of figure 4 at
[O 2 (a 1
g )] 0 = 2.6 × 10 14 cm −3 . Signs correspond to the
experimental data [23].
is determined by reaction (3):
H + O 2 (a 1
g ) → O( 3 P) + OH,
which allows us to determine the fraction of this channel
α = k 3 /(k 3 + k 4 ). The simulation results presented in figure 5
were obtained at α = 10%. It is worth mentioning that taking
into account the possible errors in determining [H] 0 (mentioned
above), i.e. decreasing the initial H atom density by 25%,
results in an increase in α up to 16-17%, which is close to the
values obtained in the processing of the experimental data [21].
It is noted in [23] that the temporal dynamics of O( 3 P)
concentration changes with increasing pressure in the range
P = 0.1-7 Torr. This may indicate that the value of α depends
on pressure. However, other explanations of this phenomenon
are possible (for example, reduction in the characteristic
diffusion time and, correspondingly, the rate of heterogeneous
losses of O( 3 P) atoms with increasing pressure). Since
the experimental data on the dependence of atomic oxygen
concentration on pressure are not given in [23], it is difficult
to draw a conclusion on the causes of this phenomenon.
Thus, a comparative analysis of experimental results
([21] and [23, 24]) allows us to draw the following conclusions.
In [21], due to the low gas pressure, the degree of conversion
of atomic hydrogen to HO 2 is low during the times considered.
Therefore, the main contribution to O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching
occurs due to the reactions with H atoms, and quenching by
HO 2 can be neglected. In [23, 24], due to a higher pressure,
atomic hydrogen is quickly converted to HO 2 and the reactions
between SDO molecules and HO 2 become dominant (HO 2 can
be in the ground and excited states). The results from numerical
simulations of data ([21] and [23]) concerning the production
of O( 3 P) atoms point out that the fraction of reaction (3)
is α = 10-20%.

Figure 6. Time dependence of the concentration of the main
components of the mixture 6% H 2 : 3% O 2 : 91% He under
the conditions of [22]: P = 3 Torr, T 0 = 600 K,
[O( 3 P)]/[O 2 ] = [O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 ] = 10%. Solid curves correspond
to k 3 /(k 3 + k 4 ) = 1, and the dashed ones to k 3 /(k 3 + k 4 ) = 0.1.
3.2. Reaction H + O 2 (a 1
g ) at T > 500 K
To analyze the effect of singlet oxygen molecules on the
ignition of combustive mixtures, the data on the rates
of reactions involving O 2 (a 1
g ) at temperatures above
450-500 K are of great interest. In [22], the quenching
rates of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules were measured in a mixture
of He : O 2 : H 2 at temperatures T 0 = 522-933 K and
pressures P = 1.5-6 Torr with an initial content of SDO
[O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 ] 0 ∼ = 10%. The residence time of the mixture
in the reaction zone (the zone of high temperature) amounted to
τ r = 2-3 ms. The temporal dynamics of O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching
due to the reactions with H atoms was measured in the
experiments. Atomic hydrogen was produced in the following
process:
O( 3 P) + H 2 → OH + H
(12)
(or in the discharge in the hydrogen flow). Based on
measurements of the ratio [O 2 (a 1
g )(t)]/[O 2 (a 1
g )] 0 and the
concentration of atomic hydrogen produced during τ r , the
total rate constant of the reactions (k 3 + k 4 ) was determined,
corresponding to a given temperature. But it was assumed
that the concentration of H atoms increases linearly with time.
By comparing the simulation results with measurements of H,
O and O 2 (a 1
g ) densities, the authors of [22] concluded that
α = k 3 /(k 3 + k 4 ) ≈ 1. However, the results of the comparison
are not given in [22].
Figure 6 presents the time evolution of a 6%
H 2 : 3% O 2 : 91% He mixture composition for the con-
ditions [22] P = 3 Torr, T 0 = 600 K, [O( 3 P)]/[O 2 ] =
[O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 ] = 10%. The solid curves correspond to
α = 1, the dashed ones are for α = 0.1. As follows from these
calculations, the change in the ratio of rate constants k 3 : k 4
by a factor of 10 has practically no effect on the temporal dy-
namics of atomic hydrogen and O 2 (a 1
g ) concentrations. A
noticeable difference is observed only for the concentrations
of OH radicals. Thus, the conclusion (α 0.2 at T 0 430 K)
based on the processing of experimental data [21, 23] does not
contradict the results of [22] obtained at higher temperatures
(T 0 = 522-933 K).
The number density of HO 2 molecules does not exceed
7 × 10 9 cm −3 under the considered conditions. Therefore,
the mechanism of O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching by HO 2 (5) proposed
in [23, 24] fails to explain the experimental data [22]. We
note that a similar conclusion was reached earlier for the
experimental conditions [21].
It is worth mentioning that the accuracy of determining the
rate constant for O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching under the conditions
of [22] at T 0
700 K, apparently, is relatively small, since
the change in the value of [O 2 (a 1
g )(t)]/[O 2 (a 1
g )] 0 is also
very small at time τ r (see figure 6) (recall that τ r
3 ms).
This is also evidenced by the scatter of the measurement
results given in [22]. With a rise in initial temperature,
the ratio [O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 (a 1
g )] 0 sufficiently increases and
the accuracy of determining the rate constant of O 2 (a 1
g )
quenching should also increase.
In [20], SDO dynamics in a hot hydrogen-oxygen mixture
was also studied. The measurements were carried out in
approximately the same range of temperatures (T 0 = 520-
1050 K) as in [22]. O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules were produced in
a microwave discharge in oxygen flow. Then O( 3 P) atoms
were removed (in reactions with mercury oxide HgO) and H 2
molecules were added. The fraction of hydrogen in the mixture
varied from 0.5% to 3%. The fraction of SDO molecules
amounts to [O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 ] 0
5%. The population of the
O 2 (a 1
g ) state was determined by measuring the intensity of
'dimole' radiation:
O 2 (a 1
g )+ O 2 (a 1
g ) → 2 • O 2 (X 3 −
g ) + hν (λ = 634 nm),
and it was also monitored by measuring the radiation intensity
at the transition:
O 2 (a 1
g ) → O 2 (X 3 −
g ) + hν (λ = 1.27 µm);
in particular, the fulfilment of the following ratio was
monitored:
(I λ=634 nm ) 2 ∝ I λ=1.27 µm .
Under the conditions of [20], SDO quenching by oxygen
molecules and in process (7) (table 1) makes no substantial
contribution to the deactivation of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules, which
was associated with the reaction O 2 (a 1
g ) + H 2 → O 2 + H 2
(2) according to the authors of [20]. As has already been
noted, the possibility of production of hydrogen atoms and
HO 2 molecules in a given mixture was not taken into account
in [20]. However, these particles, as seen from the foregoing
analysis, are actively involved in SDO quenching.
O( 3 P) atoms produced in the discharge [20] were removed
in reactions with mercury oxide. But it was noted in [27] that
the addition of NO molecules after the discharge did not lead
to the characteristic glow of excited NO *
2 molecules produced
in the reaction [30]
O( 3 P) + NO → NO *
2 .
(13)
This indicates a low concentration of atomic oxygen in the
mixing zone of H 2 and O 2 flows [20].

Plasma Sources Sci. Technol. 20 (2011) 045002
N A Popov

-3

Figure 7. Time dependence of the concentration of the main
components of the mixture O 2 : 1% H 2 : 2% O 2 (a 1
g ) : 10 −6 O( 3 P)
at T 0 = 800 K under the conditions of [20].
The intensity of NO *
2 luminescence is defined as I NO 2 =
k 13 • [O( 3 P)] • [NO], where k 13 ≈ 2 × 10 −17 photon cm 3 s −1
at P = 6 Torr and T = 300 K [30]. The minimum of NO *
2
radiation power detected by the human eye (in the range of
wavelengths λ = 500-600 nm) is 10 −9 -10 −10 W cm −3 . This
corresponds to I min
NO 2 = 10 9 -10 10 photon •cm −3 s −1 . Hence,
we can estimate the maximum number density of oxygen
atoms at which there is no noticeable glow of NO *
2 . When
[O( 3 P)]
[NO], this value is [O( 3 P)]
I min
NO 2 /k 13 =
(0.7-2.2) × 10 13 cm −3 . Furthermore, it is assumed in the
calculations that the initial dissociation degree of oxygen
molecules does not exceed [O( 3 P)]/[O 2 ] 0 3 × 10 −5 .
To describe the temporal dynamics of O 2 (a 1
g )
quenching under the conditions of [20], the evolution of
mixture composition 97% O 2 : 1% H 2 : 2% O 2 (a 1
g ) was
simulated at [O( 3 P)]/[O 2 ]
3 × 10 −5 . The shock wave
Mach number was set and gas parameters (density, pressure
and temperature) were calculated behind the shock front at
P 0 = 6 Torr, T 0 = 300 K. These parameters were used as initial
conditions for further calculations. The total number density of
molecules behind the shock wave is approximately (5.5-8.5)×
10 17 cm −3 [20]; the tube radius is R = 2.5 cm. In this case the
characteristic time of the diffusion process exceeds 30 ms (for
hydrogen atoms). The probability of heterogeneous losses of
atomic hydrogen at the quartz surface is γ = (2 -4)×10 −3 [31,
32] at T w = 500-1000 K. The total frequency of heterogeneous
recombination of H atoms (including both diffusion and
kinetic components) is equal to ν get ∼ = 15 s −1 within the
considered range of parameters. In these calculations, the
processes of diffusion and thermal conductivity are modeled
using the approximation of the corresponding characteristic
times.
Figure 7 shows the time evolution of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecule
concentration, as well as that of other components of the
hydrogen-oxygen mixture at T 0 = 800 K. The main routes
of production of chemically active radicals are the following

600

-1% H 2
-0.5% H 2
O 2 (a
1 ∆ g ) / O 2 = 2%
K
eff
, cm
3
/s
Temperature, K
Figure 8. Dependence of the effective rate constant for O 2 (a 1
g )
quenching on gas temperature. Signs correspond to the experimental
data [20] for the mixtures O 2 + 0.5% H 2 and O 2 + 1% H 2 ; curves
present the results of calculations at O 2 (a 1
g )/O 2 = 2% and
O( 3 P)/O 2 = 10 −6 for the mixtures O 2 + 1% H 2 (curves 1 and 2) and
O 2 + 0.5% H 2 (curve 3). Curves 1 were calculated without taking
into account reaction (5) at α = 0.2 (solid curve) and α = 1 (dashed
curve); curves 2 and 3 were calculated considering reaction (5).
processes:
O( 3 P) + H 2 → OH + H,
H + O 2 → OH + O( 3 P),
which ensure rapid growth of the concentration of O, H atoms
and OH radicals (see figure 7). Accordingly, the characteristic
frequency of O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching in reactions with atomic
hydrogen (reactions (3) and (4)) also increases and these
reactions become the main channel of SDO loss under these
conditions. The number density of HO 2 molecules does not
exceed 10 13 cm −3 in this case.
Based on the calculations, the effective rate constant
of O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching by H 2 molecules was determined
(K eff = ([H 2 ] 0 • τ a ) −1 , where τ a is the time at which the initial
concentration of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules decreases 2.7 times).
The obtained values were compared with the experimental
data [20].
Figure 8 presents the calculation results of the rate constant
K eff versus initial temperature (curves 1) and the measuring
data [20]. Solid curve 1 was obtained at α = 0.2 and the dashed
one was calculated at α = 1. As seen, the simulation results
agree with the experimental data at T 0 750 K. However, the
main quenching process of O 2 (a 1
g ) occurs in this case not
due to H 2 molecules, but due to hydrogen atoms (reactions (3)
and (4)). In the case of lower initial temperatures (T 0
700 K), the shape of the calculated dependence K eff (T ) differs
significantly from the results of measurements [20]. Moreover,
this difference is observed both at α = 0.2 and α = 1.
In [16], calculations of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules quenching
dynamics were also performed under the experimental
conditions of [20]. The obtained values of effective quenching
rate of SDO molecules by hydrogen are K eff ∼ = 6.7 ×
10 −16 cm 3 s −1 at T 0 = 600 K and K eff ∼ = 1.1 × 10 −14 cm 3 s −1
text.note:
Plasma Sources Sci. Technol. 20 (2011) 045002
N A Popov

T 0 = 650 K

Density, cm
-3
Time, ms
Figure 9. Time dependence of the concentrations of some
components of the mixture O 2 : 1% H 2 : 2% O 2 (a 1
g ) : 10 −6 O( 3 P)
at T 0 = 650 K under the conditions of [20].
at T 0 = 750 K. These values agree with the results of our
calculations (at α = 1) given in figure 8 (dashed curve).
That means that the authors of [16] also failed to explain the
experimental data [20] at initial temperatures below 700 K.
The reason for the sharp decrease in the effective rate
constant of O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching with falling temperature (at
T
700 K) is the significant decrease in the atomic hydrogen
concentration.
H atoms are produced mainly by the reaction
O( 3 P) + H 2 → OH + H,
(12)
which is the main reaction of chain branching. However, with
an increase in the fraction of HO 2 molecules, the following
process:
O( 3 P) + HO 2 → OH + O 2
starts to compete with (12). In this process the loss of
oxygen atoms also takes place but without chain branching.
Figure 9 shows the calculation results of the temporal
dynamics of several components of a mixture O 2 : 1% H 2 : 2%
O 2 (a 1
g ) : 10 −4 %O( 3 P) at T 0 = 650 K. The number density
of atomic hydrogen decreases almost 10 3 times compared with
the calculation results presented in figure 7 carried out at
T 0 = 800 K. Accordingly, the quenching rate of O 2 (a 1
g )
molecules is sharply reduced, as shown in figure 8 (curves 1).
Thus, the experimental data [20] on deactivation of SDO
molecules can be explained at high temperatures, T
750 K, by the quenching of O 2 (a 1
g ) by the hydrogen atoms
which are effectively produced in the considered mixture
at these temperatures. However, this process has already
failed to explain the experimental results at T
700 K.
Let us consider other possible mechanisms of deactivation of
SDO molecules capable of providing the rates of O 2 (a 1
g )
quenching, observed in [20], at T = 500-700 K.
One such mechanism could be heterogeneous quenching
of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules on the tube walls. Under the
considered conditions, deactivation of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules
at the wall proceeds in the kinetic mode. The frequency of
Table 2. Dependence of the characteristic frequencies of volume ν a
and heterogeneous ν get quenching of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules on
temperature under the conditions of [20].
T w , T (K) 500 550 600 650 700
ν get (s −1 )
1.1
1.7
2.5
3.5
4.6
ν a (s −1 )
6.0
10.
17.
25.
35.
quenching in this case is [32] ν get = (γ • u)/2R, where γ
is the probability of deactivation, u is the thermal velocity
and R is the tube radius. The formula γ = 7.4 × 10 −3 •
exp(−2240/T w ) was obtained in [32] for the probability of
O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching at quartz surface at T w = 520-825 K
which was used to estimate ν get . The corresponding values of
ν get (in the temperature range T w = 500-700 K) are given in
table 2. It was assumed that the wall temperature is equal to the
gas temperature, T w ≈ T . For comparison, the values of the
characteristic frequencies of O 2 (a 1
g ) quenching in volume
processes ν a = [H 2 ] 0 • K eff are also given in table 2. The
expression for K eff (T ) obtained in [20] was used: K eff (T ) =
2.0 × 10 −13 • exp(−2600/T ) cm 3 s −1 .
As follows from the given values, the inequation ν a
ν get
is satisfied in the whole considered range of temperatures. So,
heterogeneous deactivation of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules at the tube
walls can be ignored under the conditions of [20].
Another possible mechanism of singlet oxygen loss is
quenching of O 2 (a 1
g ) by HO 2 molecules produced in the
H 2 : O 2 : O( 3 P) mixture at these temperatures. The quenching
rate of O 2 (a 1
g ) by HO 2 molecules (reaction (5), table 1)
was determined in [25], which studied the results of O 3 : H 2 O
mixture photolysis in the Hartley band (λ = 253 nm) at
P = 67.5 Torr. The rate constant of reaction (5) was
k 5 = (3 ± 1.5) × 10 −11 cm 3 s −1 according to [25]. Such a
high value of this rate constant is explained in this case by
the quasi-resonance character of the transitions O 2 (a 1
g ) →
O 2 (X 3 −
g ) and HO 2 (A 2 A ) → HO 2 (X 2 A ) [33].
The calculation results from the model involving
reaction (5) are given in figure 8 for mixtures containing 1%
H 2 (curve 2) and 0.5% H 2 (curve 3). These results agree with
the experimental data [20] over the entire studied temperature
range. Note that the difference between the calculated values
of K eff (T ) for mixtures with different hydrogen content is
relatively small, which is also consistent with the data [20]. As
a result, the main quenching process of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules at
T 0 700 K occurs again (as in the case of higher temperatures)
not due to hydrogen molecules, as assumed by the authors
of [20], but due to the produced HO 2 molecules.
It is important that variation of the rate constants k 1 and
k 2 has a weak effect on the calculation results, so that the
experimental data [20] cannot be used to determine the rate
constants of reactions of O 2 (a 1
g ) with hydrogen molecules
(reactions (1) and (2)) more precisely.
3.3. Effect of O 2 (a 1
g ) admixtures on the ignition of H 2 : O 2
mixtures
Here we analyze the effect of the obtained data on the rates
of O 2 (a 1
g ) reactions (3)-(5) on the ignition of hydrogen-
oxygen mixtures. The calculations of the dependence of

Plasma Sources Sci. Technol. 20 (2011) 045002
N A Popov

P
H 2 : air
Ignition delay time,
µs
Temperature, K
Figure 10. Dependences of the ignition delay time of a
stoichiometric H 2 : air mixture on the initial temperature at
P = 1 atm and at the various admixtures of O 2 (a 1
g ) and O( 3 P)
(α = 0.2). Signs correspond to the experimental data [34, 35],
curves correspond to the calculation results without admixtures
(curve 1) and with admixtures of 1% [O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 ] (curve 2);
0.1% [O( 3 P)]/[O 2 ] (curve 3) and 1% [O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 ] + 0.1%
[O( 3 P)]/[O 2 ] (curve 4).

1 ∆ g )

Temperature, K
Figure 11. Temporal dynamics of the temperature and
concentrations of some components of a stoichiometric H 2 : air
mixture at P = 1 atm, T 0 = 900 K and [O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 ] 0 = 1%.
ignition delay times on initial temperature were performed
for different fractions of reaction (3). The rate constant of
reaction (1) was taken as in [15] (table 1) while the fraction
of reaction (3), α = k 3 /(k 3 + k 4 ), was varied from 0.1 to 1.
Figure 10 presents the calculation results of ignition delay
times of stoichiometric H 2 : air mixture (in the case of α = 0.2)
at P = 1 atm and at different initial concentrations of singlet
oxygen O 2 (a 1
g ) and O( 3 P) atoms. All results were compared
with curve 1 obtained at concentrations [O 2 (a 1
g )] 0 =
[O( 3 P)] 0 = 0. Curve 2 corresponds to the initial ratio
[O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 ] 0 = 1%. As can be seen, the addition of 1%
O 2 (a 1
g ) does not lead to a significant decrease in the ignition
temperature threshold which distinguishes the obtained results
from those given in [14, 15].
Figure 11 shows the calculations of the temporal dynamics
of the main components and the temperature of the H 2 : air
mixture at P = 1 atm, [O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 ] 0 = 1%, T 0 = 900 K.
Number density of HO 2 molecules is (1-6) × 10 14 cm −3 over
a time range t = 100-700 µs which leads to a rapid quenching
of SDO molecules by these particles. During the ignition
time (τ ind ∼ = 740 µs) the concentration of singlet oxygen
reduced by more than 100 times. We note some increase in
the concentration of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules over the time range
720-780 µs which is associated with the intensification of the
process O + OH → H + O 2 (a 1
g ) (the rate constant k(T )
was taken from [14]). In addition, the rate of SDO quenching
by HO 2 molecules decreases over this time range as their
density falls.
Thus, a relatively small effect of SDO admixtures on
the ignition of hydrogen-oxygen mixtures occurs due to the
rapid quenching of O 2 (a 1
g ) by HO 2 molecules. The HO 2
molecules are actively produced in H 2 : O 2 mixtures under the
considered conditions.
One of the main sources of singlet oxygen is an electrical
discharge [10], which allows us to achieve a sufficiently high
degree of excitation of [O 2 (a 1
g )]/[O 2 ]. This is confirmed by
experimental results ([8-10] and so on) obtained for different
types of discharges. However, as SDO is produced by an
electric discharge, a large fraction of discharge energy can be
spent on the dissociation of O 2 molecules. In this case it is
necessary to consider the total effect (admixtures of O 2 (a 1
g )
and atomic oxygen) on the ignition of combustible mixtures.
An example of such a calculation is presented in figure 10
(curves 3 and 4) which shows the ignition delay times of
a H 2 : air mixture with addition of [O( 3 P)]/[O 2 ] = 0.1%
(curve 3) and with the total effect of 1% O 2 (a 1
g ) and
0.1% O( 3 P) (curve 4). As seen, adding 0.1% oxygen atoms
results in a significant decrease in the induction delay time
and in the ignition temperature threshold of the considered
mixture. Additional admixing of another 1% O 2 (a 1
g ) to this
mixture does not give a noticeable improvement in ignition
characteristics, as is evident from the comparison of curves
3 and 4. That is, in the presence of even a small initial
concentration of atomic particles, the effect of SDO molecules
reduces in comparison with the unexcited ([O( 3 P)] 0 = 0)
mixture. The reason for this is that the addition of O( 3 P)
atoms leads to a reduction of the role of reaction (1) as the
chain initiation process. The contribution of the reaction of
chain branching (3) is also small at the given temperatures [1].
Therefore, under the considered conditions, the effect of singlet
oxygen admixtures reduces to only additional heating of the
mixture in the process of its deactivation.
4. Conclusions
A kinetic model describing the effect of SDO O 2 (a 1
g )
admixtures on the evolution of hydrogen-oxygen mixtures
was developed. The dynamics of SDO quenching in H 2 : O 2
mixtures was calculated under the experimental conditions
of [20-24] in the temperature range T 0 = 300-1050 K. The
possibility of describing the entire set of experimental data
[20-24] in the framework of the model was illustrated.
The effect of singlet oxygen O 2 (a 1
g ) admixtures on
the ignition of H 2 : O 2 mixtures was studied. The SDO
text.note:
Plasma Sources Sci. Technol. 20 (2011) 045002
N A Popov
text.body:
molecules can participate in the reactions of both chain
initiation (O 2 (a 1
g ) + H 2 → OH + OH)) and chain branching
(O 2 (a 1
g ) + H → OH + O). By comparing the results of
calculations with experimental data, the following conclusions
on the rates of these processes can be drawn. Most of the
collisions of SDO molecules with atomic hydrogen O 2 (a 1
g )+
H lead to quenching of O 2 (a 1
g ) molecules (reaction (4)).
Share of this channel is more than 80% and the reaction of
chain branching is observed only in 10-20% of the cases.
It is not possible to determine the rate constant of the
process O 2 (a 1
g ) + H 2 → OH + OH (1) on the basis of
available experimental data. So, the values of k 1 (T ) remain
undetermined.
An important process that determines the effect of SDO
molecules on the ignition characteristics of hydrogen-oxygen
mixtures is its deactivation by HO 2 molecules. According
to [25, 33], this reaction is very effective. As a result, in
H 2 : O 2 mixtures at high pressures, where the concentration
of produced HO 2 molecules can be sufficiently high, the effect
of singlet oxygen on the ignition delay times of these mixtures
is relatively weak. This effect becomes even less noticeable if
the mixture contains an initial concentration of oxygen atoms.
The last case is typical when electrical discharge systems are
used for the production of singlet oxygen. The presence of even
a small (10 −4 ) initial concentration of atomic oxygen reduces
the effect of O 2 (a 1
g ) admixtures on the processes of ignition
to only additional heating of the mixture in the process of SDO
deactivation.
Thus, to reduce the ignition delay time and decrease the
temperature threshold of combustive mixtures, the use of gas
discharge systems providing the efficient production of atomic
particles is recommended.
text.div:
Acknowledgments
This work was partially supported by the Russian Agency of
Technologies and Innovations (Contract No 02.740.11.5108),
the International Science and Technology Center (Project No
3833p) and the Grant for Support of Leading Scientific Schools
(Grant No 3322.2010.2).
